questions.title: Continuity Equation Application
questions.question_text: Water flows through a pipe that narrows from diameter $D_1 = 10\,\text{cm}$ to $D_2 = 5\,\text{cm}$. If the velocity at the wider section is $v_1 = 2\,\text{m/s}$, what is the velocity at the narrower section?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Using continuity equation $A_1v_1 = A_2v_2$, we get $v_2 = v_1(D_1/D_2)^2 = 2(10/5)^2 = 8\,\text{m/s}$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Remember that for circular pipes, $A = \pi D^2/4$, so the velocity ratio depends on $(D_1/D_2)^2$

questions.title: Bernoulli's Equation
questions.question_text: For steady, incompressible flow along a streamline, Bernoulli's equation states:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! This is the standard form of Bernoulli's equation with pressure, kinetic energy per unit volume, and potential energy per unit volume terms
questions.feedback_incorrect: Check the coefficients carefully - kinetic energy per unit volume is $\frac{1}{2}\rho v^2$ and potential energy per unit volume is $\rho gz$

questions.title: Pressure Drop Calculation
questions.question_text: Water ($\rho = 1000\,\text{kg/m}^3$) flows horizontally through a venturi meter. At the inlet, $p_1 = 200\,\text{kPa}$ and $v_1 = 3\,\text{m/s}$. At the throat, $v_2 = 12\,\text{m/s}$. Find the pressure at the throat in kPa.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Using Bernoulli's equation: $p_2 = p_1 + \frac{1}{2}\rho(v_1^2 - v_2^2) = 200000 + \frac{1}{2}(1000)(9 - 144) = 132500\,\text{Pa} = 132.5\,\text{kPa}$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Apply Bernoulli's equation for horizontal flow: $p_1 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_1^2 = p_2 + \frac{1}{2}\rho v_2^2$

questions.title: Reynolds Number
questions.question_text: The Reynolds number for pipe flow is defined as:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Reynolds number is the ratio of inertial forces to viscous forces: $Re = \frac{\rho v D}{\mu}$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Reynolds number represents the ratio of inertial forces ($\rho v^2$) to viscous forces ($\mu v/D$)

questions.title: Laminar vs Turbulent Flow
questions.question_text: For flow in a circular pipe, the transition from laminar to turbulent flow typically occurs at:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The critical Reynolds number for pipe flow is approximately 2300
questions.feedback_incorrect: The critical Reynolds number for circular pipe flow is around 2300, though transition can occur between 2000-4000

questions.title: Darcy-Weisbach Equation
questions.question_text: Water flows through a horizontal pipe with diameter $D = 5\,\text{cm}$, length $L = 100\,\text{m}$, and friction factor $f = 0.02$. If the velocity is $v = 2\,\text{m/s}$, calculate the pressure drop in kPa.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Using Darcy-Weisbach: $\Delta p = f\frac{L}{D}\frac{\rho v^2}{2} = 0.02\frac{100}{0.05}\frac{1000 \times 4}{2} = 160000\,\text{Pa} = 160\,\text{kPa}$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use the Darcy-Weisbach equation: $\Delta p = f\frac{L}{D}\frac{\rho v^2}{2}$

questions.title: Hydrostatic Pressure
questions.question_text: The pressure at depth $h$ in a static fluid with density $\rho$ is:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Hydrostatic pressure increases linearly with depth: $p = p_0 + \rho gh$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Remember that pressure in a static fluid increases due to the weight of fluid above: $dp/dz = \rho g$

questions.title: Torricelli's Law
questions.question_text: A tank contains water to a height of $h = 4\,\text{m}$ above an orifice. What is the velocity of water exiting the orifice in m/s? (Use $g = 9.81\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Using Torricelli's law: $v = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 4} = 8.86\,\text{m/s}$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Apply Torricelli's law for flow from a tank: $v = \sqrt{2gh}$

questions.title: Viscosity Definition
questions.question_text: Dynamic viscosity $\mu$ relates shear stress to:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Newton's law of viscosity states that shear stress is proportional to velocity gradient: $\tau = \mu \frac{du}{dy}$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Viscosity relates shear stress to the rate of shear deformation, which is the velocity gradient

questions.title: Poiseuille Flow
questions.question_text: For laminar flow in a circular pipe, the maximum velocity is $u_{max} = 3\,\text{m/s}$. What is the average velocity in m/s?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! For Poiseuille flow, the average velocity is half the maximum: $u_{avg} = \frac{u_{max}}{2} = \frac{3}{2} = 1.5\,\text{m/s}$
questions.feedback_incorrect: In laminar pipe flow, the velocity profile is parabolic and $u_{avg} = u_{max}/2$

questions.title: Boundary Layer Concept
questions.question_text: The boundary layer thickness $\delta$ is conventionally defined as the distance from the wall where:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Boundary layer thickness is defined where velocity reaches 99% of free stream velocity
questions.feedback_incorrect: The conventional definition uses 99% of the free stream velocity to define boundary layer thickness

questions.title: Drag Force
questions.question_text: The drag force on a body moving through a fluid is given by:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Drag force depends on dynamic pressure $\frac{1}{2}\rho v^2$, drag coefficient $C_D$, and frontal area $A$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Drag force is proportional to dynamic pressure: $\frac{1}{2}\rho v^2$

questions.title: Pump Power Calculation
questions.question_text: A pump delivers water at $Q = 0.05\,\text{m}^3/\text{s}$ with a head increase of $H = 20\,\text{m}$. If the pump efficiency is $\eta = 0.8$, what is the required power input in kW? (Use $\rho = 1000\,\text{kg/m}^3$, $g = 9.81\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Power = $\frac{\rho g Q H}{\eta} = \frac{1000 \times 9.81 \times 0.05 \times 20}{0.8} = 12262.5\,\text{W} = 12.26\,\text{kW}$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use the pump power equation: $P = \frac{\rho g Q H}{\eta}$ where $\eta$ is efficiency

questions.title: Compressible Flow
questions.question_text: Compressibility effects become significant when the Mach number $Ma > 0.3$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Compressibility effects are generally considered significant for Mach numbers greater than 0.3
questions.feedback_incorrect: The rule of thumb is that compressibility effects become important when $Ma > 0.3$

questions.title: Surface Tension
questions.question_text: The Weber number, which characterizes the relative importance of inertial forces to surface tension forces, is defined as:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Weber number is the ratio of inertial forces to surface tension forces: $We = \frac{\rho v^2 L}{\sigma}$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Weber number compares inertial forces ($\rho v^2$) to surface tension forces ($\sigma/L$)

questions.title: Manometer Reading
questions.question_text: A U-tube manometer contains mercury ($\rho_{Hg} = 13600\,\text{kg/m}^3$) and measures a pressure difference. If the mercury height difference is $h = 25\,\text{cm}$, what is the pressure difference in kPa? (Use $g = 9.81\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Pressure difference = $\rho_{Hg} g h = 13600 \times 9.81 \times 0.25 = 33354\,\text{Pa} = 33.35\,\text{kPa}$
questions.feedback_incorrect: For a manometer, pressure difference equals the hydrostatic pressure of the manometer fluid: $\Delta p = \rho g h$

questions.title: Flow Measurement
questions.question_text: A pitot tube measures:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! A pitot tube measures stagnation pressure (total pressure) at the stagnation point
questions.feedback_incorrect: A pitot tube brings the flow to rest and measures the total or stagnation pressure

questions.title: Hydraulic Diameter
questions.question_text: For a rectangular duct with width $w = 20\,\text{cm}$ and height $h = 10\,\text{cm}$, calculate the hydraulic diameter in cm.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Hydraulic diameter is defined as $D_h = \frac{4A}{P}$ where $A$ is cross-sectional area and $P$ is wetted perimeter

questions.title: Cavitation
questions.question_text: Cavitation occurs when:
choices: Local pressure drops below vapor pressure
questions.correct_answer: Local pressure drops below vapor pressure
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Cavitation occurs when local pressure falls below the vapor pressure of the liquid
questions.feedback_incorrect: Cavitation is caused by pressure dropping below vapor pressure, causing liquid to vaporize

questions.title: Open Channel Flow
questions.question_text: Water flows in a rectangular channel with width $b = 2\,\text{m}$ and depth $y = 1.5\,\text{m}$. If the velocity is $v = 2\,\text{m/s}$, calculate the Froude number. (Use $g = 9.81\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $Fr = \frac{v}{\sqrt{gy}} = \frac{2}{\sqrt{9.81 \times 1.5}} = \frac{2}{3.836} = 0.523$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Froude number for open channel flow is $Fr = \frac{v}{\sqrt{gy}}$ where $y$ is the flow depth
